quoteFirst: The Canadian attack went well, but very stiff opposition was encountered in Marquion, so that the 56th Division attack from the Blue line had to be postponed from
quoteLast: to 3.28 p.m. Excellent work was done by the 512th and 513th Field Companies, R.E. (56th Division), in bridging the Canal at Marquion.
title: The War History of the 4th Battalion, the London Regiment (Royal Fusiliers), 1914-1919
author: Grimwade, F. Clive

quoteFirst: IV
quoteLast: With heavy trays she walks about five miles V 3 to 5 P.M. “Free” and nowhere to go VI 5 to 8 P.M. Carrying trays and walking many miles VII 9 P.M. Exhausted—Home and to bed VIII 6 A.M. The daily grind begins again
title: Behind the scenes in a restaurant: A study of 1017 women restaurant employees
author: Consumers' League of New York City

quoteFirst: At 5.30 a.m. on the 27th September the crash of the barrage announced the opening of the Canadian Corps attack. The enemy's retaliation was slight and had practically ceased by 6 a.m. The 1/4th Londons' area was occupied by eight brigades of field guns engaged in firing a flank barrage to the main attack until
quoteLast: , when they were to switch on a creeping barrage for the attack northwards along the Canal. Additional flank protection was furnished by six companies of machine-guns also in our area.
title: The War History of the 4th Battalion, the London Regiment (Royal Fusiliers), 1914-1919
author: Grimwade, F. Clive

quoteFirst: Now the position of this dial being such that its end _a m_ must face the south, and the upper part of it or the line _a f_ lying parallel to the _equinoctial_, it is evident that the sun at noon will shine just along the line _a b_, and _m l_; therefore you must place 12 at _b_ and _l_, then from
quoteLast: the shadow of the corner _a_ will pass along the line _b c_, therefore take from the quadrant _h n_, the distance _h o_, and set it from 12 to 1. Take also _h p_ and set it from 12 to 2, _h q_ being equal to _b c_; at _c_ you may place 3 where the shadow of the corner _a_ goes quite off the dial at _c_, or 3 o'clock in the afternoon; at this time the shadow of the corner _i_ will appear on the side _h g_ at _q_ or 3 o'clock, where place the figure 3; the shadow will then ascend to _p_ at 4, to _o_ at 5; at 6 there will be no shadow, the sun shining right
title: The Mirror of Literature, Amusement, and Instruction. Volume 17, No. 493, June 11, 1831

quoteFirst: But the village of Marquion was on the east of the canal, and on the Arras-Cambrai road, and at 11.45 a.m. the village was still holding out, which made it impossible for the 169th Brigade to keep to the time-table and be in position for attack by
quoteLast: It was therefore decided to postpone the attack until 3.28 p.m.
title: The 56th Division (1st London Territorial Division)
author: Dudley Ward, C. H. (Charles Humble), 1879-; Horne, Henry, 1861-1929 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: Enemy retaliation on the 56th Division was slight, and practically ceased by 5.40 a.m. But as the morning progressed it became apparent that the Canadians were meeting with strong opposition on the extreme left. They were timed to reach a line immediately south of Sauchy by mid-day, and the 169th Brigade was to carry on the attack from there at
title: The 56th Division (1st London Territorial Division)

quoteFirst: , they began to traverse the northern parts of Kent, while light, drifting upper clouds gave indication of other possible currents. Mr. Hollond was precise in the determination of times and of all readings and we learn that at exactly
quoteLast: they were crossing the Medway, six miles west of Rochester, while at 4.5 p.m. the lofty towers of Canterbury were well in view, two miles to the east, and here a little function was well carried out. Green had twice ascended from this city under patronage of the authorities, and the idea occurred to the party that it would be a graceful compliment to drop a message to the Mayor as they passed.
title: The Dominion of the Air: The Story of Aerial Navigation
author: Bacon, John M. (John Mackenzie), 1846-1904

quoteFirst: 6 kilos was fed on September 4, 1906, with an aqueous extract representing 3,500 grams of the dried _Aragallus lamberti_, 1,000 c.c. of water being used. The temperature at the time of feeding was 104.3°F. At
quoteLast: the animal on rising to its feet developed a slight tremor of the fore legs and showed marked disinclination to stand on its feet. The temperature was 104°F. The animal died at 4.25 p.m. The post-mortem was negative, save for some reddening of the second stomach.
title: Barium: A Cause of the Loco-Weed Disease
author: Crawford, Albert Cornelius
